par.text: Pure tungsten is a silvery-white metal, soft enough to be cut with a metal-cutting saw, but small amounts of additives or impurities impart hardness and brittleness to it. Tungsten has the highest melting point of any element: 3422

C. When heated, it emits a bright, white light. It is relatively inert, resistant to water, acids and alkalis. Large quantities of tungsten are used for the preparation of tungsten carbide – WC, an exceptionally hard substance. Tungsten was discovered by the Swedish chemist Wilhelm Scheele in 1781 and isolated by the brothers Juan, Jose and Fausto D'Elhuayar in 1783. The name is derived from the Swedish words
